p.k: Wenzel Fuchs, Berlin Philharmonic, Sir Simon Rattle
p.d: In 1909, Claude Debussy was admitted by Gabriel Fauré to the Conseil Supérieur (Board of Directors) of the Parisian Conservatory. One of the first tasks connected to this admission was to supply the clarinet students with suitable exam pieces. This he did, composing a 'Premiere rhapsodie' for clarinet and piano, dedicated to clarinet teacher Prosper Mimart and first performed at the exams in July 1910. The piece was a great success and, consequently, Debussy made another version for clarinet and orchestra in 1911.
